natural problem:
The first six rows of Pascal's triangle are shown below, beginning with row 0.

How many of the first 100 rows contain at least one even entry and no odd entries other than $1$? (Rows 2 and 4 have this property, for example.)

\begin{tabular}{ccccccccccc}
&&&&&1&&&&&\\
&&&&1&&1&&&&\\
&&&1&&2&&1&&&\\
&&1&&3&&3&&1&&\\
&1&&4&&6&&4&&1&\\
1&&5&&10&&10&&5&&1\\
\end{tabular}
natural solution: Starting with row $0$, the $k^\text{th}$ row has the numbers \[\binom{k}{0},\binom{k}{1},\binom{k}{2},\ldots,\binom{k}{k} .\]For every number in the row except the first and last values to be even, $k$ must only have even factors, so it must be a power of $2$.
Since the highest power of $2$ under $100$ is $2^6=64$, $\boxed{6}$ of the first 100 rows have only even numbers besides $1$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pascals_triangle :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "pascals_triangle 0 = [1]"
and h1 : "pascals_triangle 1 = [1, 1]"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> pascals_triangle n = 
            (map (\<lambda>(a, b). a + b) (zip ([1] @ (pascals_triangle (n - 1))) ((pascals_triangle (n - 1)) @ [1])))"
and h3 : "(\<lambda>n. filter (\<lambda>l. list_all (\<lambda>x. x = 1 \<or> even x) l) (map pascals_triangle [0..<100])) = 6"
shows  "count_rows_with_even_entries_and_no_odd_entries_except_1 = 6"
a_0.formal solution:

\begin{tabular}{ccccccccccc}

&&&&1&&1&&&&\\
&&&1&&2&&1&&&\\
&&1&&3&&3&&1&&\\
&1&&4&&6&&4&&1&\\
1&&5&&10&&10&&5&&1\\
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Starting with row $0$, the $k^\text{th}$ row has the numbers \[\binom{k}{0},\binom{k}{1},\binom{k}{2},\ldots,\binom{k}{k} .\]For every number in the row except the first and last values to be even, $k$ must only have even factors, so it must be a power of $2$.
 Since the highest power of $2$ under $100$ is $2^6=64$, $\boxed{6}$ of the first 100 rows have only even numbers besides $1$.
 *)

theorem
fixes pascals_triangle :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "pascals_triangle 0 = [1]"
and h1 : "pascals_triangle 1 = [1, 1]"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> pascals_triangle n = 
            (map (\<lambda>(a, b). a + b) (zip ([1] @ (pascals_triangle (n - 1))) ((pascals_triangle (n - 1)) @ [1])))"
and h3 : "(\<lambda>n. filter (\<lambda>l. list_all (\<lambda>x. x = 1 \<or> even x) l) (map pascals_triangle [0..<100])) = 6"
shows  "count_rows_with_even_entries_and_no_odd_entries_except_1 = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider Pascal's Triangle, where the first two rows are [1] and [1, 1] and each subsequent row is constructed by adding the neighboring pairs of numbers in the previous row, with 1s at the beginning and end of each row. How many rows from the first 100 rows of Pascal's Triangle contain only even numbers and 1s? The final answer is 6.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes row :: nat
and pascal_triangle :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "pascal_triangle 0 = [1]"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. pascal_triangle (Suc n) = [1] @ (zipWith (\<lambda> x y. x + y) (pascal_triangle n) (tail (pascal_triangle n))) @ [1]"
and h2 : "\<forall> row. row < 100 \<longrightarrow> (list_all (\<lambda> x. x = 1 \<or> even x) (pascal_triangle row)) = (row \<in> {2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64})"
shows  "card {row. row < 100 \<and> list_all (\<lambda> x. x = 1 \<or> even x) (pascal_triangle row)} = 6"

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes row :: nat and pascal_triangle :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "pascal_triangle 0 = [1]"
and h1 : "pascal_triangle 1 = [1, 1]"
and h2 : "pascal_triangle 2 = [1, 2, 1]"
and h3 : "pascal_triangle 3 = [1, 3, 3, 1]"
and h4 : "pascal_triangle 4 = [1, 4, 6, 4, 1]"
and h5 : "pascal_triangle 5 = [1, 5, 10, 10, 5, 1]"
and h6 : "\<forall> row. row \<ge> 6 \<longrightarrow> pascal_triangle row = (1 # [pascal_triangle (row - 1) ! i + pascal_triangle (row - 1) ! (i + 1) . i \<leftarrow> [0..<length (pascal_triangle (row - 1)) - 1]] @ [1])"
and h7 : "count {row. row \<in> {0..<100} \<and> (\<forall>entry\<in>set (pascal_triangle row) - {1}. even entry)} \<ge> 1"
shows  "count {row. row \<in> {0..<100} \<and> (\<forall>entry\<in>set (pascal_triangle row) - {1}. even entry)} = 6"
a_2.formal solution:

&&1&&3&&3&&1&&\\
&1&&4&&6&&4&&1&\\
1&&5&&10&&10&&5&&1\\
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Starting with row $0$, the $k^\text{th}$ row has the numbers \[\binom{k}{0},\binom{k}{1},\binom{k}{2},\ldots,\binom{k}{k} .\]For every number in the row except the first and last values to be even, $k$ must only have even factors, so it must be a power of $2$.
 Since the highest power of $2$ under $100$ is $2^6=64$, $\boxed{6}$ of the first 100 rows have only even numbers besides $1$.
 *)

and h3 : "pascal_triangle 3 = [1, 3, 3, 1]"

a_2.informal problem: In Pascal's Triangle, find the number of rows, between row 0 and row 99, such that all the non-1 entries are even. The final answer is 6.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pascals_triangle :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "pascals_triangle 0 = [1]"
and h1 : "pascals_triangle 1 = [1, 1]"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> pascals_triangle n = (1 # map (\<lambda>i. (pascals_triangle (n - 1)) ! i + (pascals_triangle (n - 1)) ! (i - 1)) [1 ..< length (pascals_triangle (n - 1))] @ [1])"
and h3 : "even_entries_no_odd_entries = (\<lambda> row. list_all even (filter (\<lambda> x. x \<noteq> 1) row))"
shows  "card {n. n \<in> {0 ..< 100} \<and> even_entries_no_odd_entries (pascals_triangle n)} = 6"

Define a function "even_entries_no_odd_entries" that takes a row and returns true if all the entries in the row, except for 1s, are even. How many rows are there in the first 100 rows of Pascal's triangle that satisfy the "even_entries_no_odd_entries" condition? The final answer is 6.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pascals_triangle :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "pascals_triangle = (\<lambda>n. [binomial n k. k \<leftarrow> [0..n]])"
and h1 : "even_entries_no_odd_entries = (\<lambda>row. list_all even (tl row) \<and> (\<forall>x \<in> set (tl row). x \<noteq> 1))"
and h2 : "rows_with_property = {n. n \<in> {0..<100} \<and> even_entries_no_odd_entries (pascals_triangle n)}"
shows  "card rows_with_property = 6"

1&&5&&10&&10&&5&&1\\

Find the number of rows in the first 100 rows (0 to 99) of Pascal's Triangle that satisfy this property. The final answer is 6.

shows  "length (filter (\<lambda> r. list_all (\<lambda> x. x = 1 \<or> even x) (nth pascals_triangle r)) [0..<100]) = 6"

shows  "count_rows_with_property pascal_triangle 100 (\<lambda> row. (\<forall> x \<in> set row. even x \<or> x = 1)) = 6"

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pascal_triangle :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "pascal_triangle 0 = [1]"

and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> pascal_triangle n = (1 # [a + b. a \<leftarrow> pascal_triangle (n - 1), b \<leftarrow> pascal_triangle (n - 1) (tl)]) @ [1]"
and h3 : "count_rows_with_even_entries_and_no_odd_entries_other_than_1 pascal_triangle 100 = 6"
shows  "count_rows_with_even_entries_and_no_odd_entries_other_than_1 pascal_triangle 100 = 6"

fixes pascal_triangle :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "pascal_triangle 0 = [1]"

a_7.informal problem: A Pascal's Triangle is constructed with each row being the coefficients of a binomial expansion. The first row is [1], the second row is [1, 1], and each subsequent row is generated by adding the adjacent elements of the previous row and appending 1 at the beginning and end of the row. For example, the third row is [1, 2, 1], and the fourth row is [1, 3, 3, 1]. Find the number of rows in the first 100 rows of Pascal's Triangle that have only even entries, except for the 1's at the beginning and end of each row. The final answer is 6.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pascal :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "pascal 0 = [1]"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. pascal (Suc n) = zipWith (+) ([0] @ pascal n) (pascal n @ [0])"
and h2 : "count_rows_with_property pascal 100 = 6"
and h3 : "count_rows_with_property pascal n = card {i. i < n \<and> even_entries_no_odd_other_than_1 (pascal i)}"
and h4 : "even_entries_no_odd_other_than_1 xs = (list_all even (filter (\<lambda> x. x \<noteq> 1) xs))"
shows  "count_rows_with_property pascal 100 = 6"

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pascal_triangle :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list" and even_entries :: "nat list \<Rightarrow> bool" and odd_entries :: "nat list \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. pascal_triangle n = (rows of Pascal's triangle)"
and h1 : "\<forall> row. even_entries row = (row contains at least one even entry and no odd entries other than 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall> row. odd_entries row = (row contains only odd entries and possibly 1)"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {2, 4} \<longrightarrow> even_entries (pascal_triangle n)"
and h4 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {0, 1, 3, 5} \<longrightarrow> odd_entries (pascal_triangle n)"
shows  "card {n. n \<in> {0..99} \<and> even_entries (pascal_triangle n)} = 6"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The first six rows of Pascal's triangle are shown below, beginning with row 0.

How many of the first 100 rows contain at least one even entry and no odd entries other than $1$? (Rows 2 and 4 have this property, for example.)

\begin{tabular}{ccccccccccc}
&&&&&1&&&&&\\
&&&&1&&1&&&&\\
&&&1&&2&&1&&&\\
&&1&&3&&3&&1&&\\
&1&&4&&6&&4&&1&\\
1&&5&&10&&10&&5&&1\\
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Starting with row $0$, the $k^\text{th}$ row has the numbers \[\binom{k}{0},\binom{k}{1},\binom{k}{2},\ldots,\binom{k}{k} .\]For every number in the row except the first and last values to be even, $k$ must only have even factors, so it must be a power of $2$.
 Since the highest power of $2$ under $100$ is $2^6=64$, $\boxed{6}$ of the first 100 rows have only even numbers besides $1$.
 *)

theorem
fixes pascal_triangle :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list" and even_entries :: "nat list \<Rightarrow> bool" and odd_entries :: "nat list \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. pascal_triangle n = (rows of Pascal's triangle)"
and h1 : "\<forall> row. even_entries row = (row contains at least one even entry and no odd entries other than 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall> row. odd_entries row = (row contains only odd entries and possibly 1)"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {2, 4} \<longrightarrow> even_entries (pascal_triangle n)"
and h4 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {0, 1, 3, 5} \<longrightarrow> odd_entries (pascal_triangle n)"
shows  "card {n. n \<in> {0..99} \<and> even_entries (pascal_triangle n)} = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In Pascal's triangle, let an even row be one that contains at least one even entry and no odd entries other than 1, and an odd row be one that contains only odd entries and possibly 1. How many even rows are there among the first 100 rows of Pascal's triangle? The final answer is 6.
